header.title: The Egyptian Revival or The Ever-Coming Son in The Light of The Tarot

central_thesis: Frater Achad proposes a "Reformed Astrological Order" for attributing the Tarot Trumps to the Paths of the Qabalistic Tree of Life. This re-ordering, based on reversing the traditional "Serpent of Wisdom" ascent from Malkuth, is argued to restore a lost "Primitive Universal Tradition," revealing a harmonious astrological symbolism and clarifying the mysteries of the "Ever-Coming Son" (Horus) and the "New Aeon" (Age of Aquarius). This system leads humanity to a profound understanding of the Divine Will and the path to Cosmic Consciousness.

structure_content.summary: This chapter traces the historical and mythological evolution of Egyptian divine concepts, from the primal Mother and Child (Sut-Typhon) to later solar deities like Aten and Ra, and the dual nature of Horus. It connects these ancient traditions to the concept of the "Ever-Coming Son" and contextualizes them within astrological ages, culminating in the proclamation of the New Aeon of Ra-Hoor-Khuit around 1904. The author sets the stage for demonstrating how his "Reformed Astrological Order" for the Tarot and Tree of Life will reveal these deeper truths.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Essence of the Practical Qabalah
structure_content.summary: This chapter provides a foundational overview of the Qabalistic Tree of Life, describing the Ten Sephiroth as emanations of Infinite Light and the basis for understanding creation. It details the Supernal Triad (Kether, Chokmah, Binah), the Formative World, and Malkuth, emphasizing the goal of returning to Unity and achieving "The Great Work" by uniting the Microcosm with the Macrocosm. The author highlights how the Qabalah's numerical system and the 32 Paths of Wisdom serve as a method for classifying and ultimately comprehending all ideas in the universe.

structure_content.chapter_title: More Light on the Tarot Trumps
structure_content.summary: This chapter meticulously details the symbolism of specific Tarot Trumps when placed on the Paths of the Tree of Life according to the author's "Reformed Astrological Order." It explains the attributions of Kether, Chokmah, Binah, and their connecting Paths (e.g., "The Wheel of Fortune," "The Universe," "The Star," "The Sun," "The Devil," "Judgment") to planets, zodiacal signs, and mythological figures. The analysis explores how these re-attributions clarify the dual traditions of Light and Darkness, their reconciliation in Tiphereth, and the roles of key figures and concepts like IU, Harpocrates, and the Great Mother in this re-envisioned system.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Sun, The Devil, and the Redeemer
structure_content.summary: This chapter delves deeper into the reconciliation of dual wills (Divine and Personal) and the traditions of Light and Darkness, particularly as they manifest in Tiphereth and Malkuth. It re-interprets "The Beast" (666) as representing Man in his complete nature (animal, human, spiritual, divine) and clarifies the symbolism of "The Devil" as the illusion of Time. The chapter provides Qabalistic numerations to support the "Reformed Order" for both the "Dark Tradition" (555 for Obscurity) and "Light Tradition" (220/222 for Thelema/Whiteness), arguing that the New Aeon offers humanity a unique opportunity for true wisdom and understanding, transcending past errors.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Mystery of Babalon and the Beast
structure_content.summary: This chapter further explores "The Beast" as the Soul of Humanity and the concept of "ON" (120), linking it to conscious cooperation with the Divine Purpose. It re-examines "The Hanged Man" as the "Redeemer" and the process of raising Malkuth (the Fallen Daughter) to unity with the Son and Mother, ultimately expanding consciousness to Nuit and Hadit. The author clarifies the true nature of the Infinite (Nuit as Infinitely Great, Hadit as Infinitely Small) and the role of the Crowned Child (Ra-Hoor-Khuit) as the manifestation of the One Thing, asserting that these mysteries can be spiritually discerned in the current age.

structure_content.chapter_title: Further Light on the Tree of Life
structure_content.summary: This chapter positions the Tree of Life as a multi-dimensional Divine Plan, which, when understood through the "Reformed Order," allows human consciousness to grasp the New Aeon's potential. It maps the cyclical appearances of Horus through various astrological ages (Leo, Cancer, Gemini, Taurus, Aries, Pisces), explaining how each age influenced human understanding of the Divine. The chapter emphasizes that the current Age of Aquarius, with its unique "Reciprocal Path" above the Abyss, offers an unprecedented opportunity for true Wisdom and Understanding, enabling humanity to transcend past limitations and embrace their "Divine Will."

This chapter provides an in-depth interpretation of the central Thelemic dictum, "Do what thou wilt shall be the whole of the Law," distinguishing it from mere license and presenting it as a "touchstone" for aligning personal will with Divine Will. The author recounts his personal experience with the Law, describing how it led to inner peace, clarity, and effective action by fostering non-interference with others and cooperation with the "True Will of Humanity." He contrasts this path with the "Black Tradition" (selfish will) and the "White Brotherhood" (narrow interpretation), asserting that embracing the Divine Law leads to conscious fulfillment of Destiny and becoming "Ever-Coming Sons of God."

structure_content.chapter_title: The Tradition of the Golden Age
structure_content.summary: This concluding chapter ties together the book's themes, elaborating on Qabalistic formulae and their connection to overcoming death and accessing the Holy Spirit via the "1923 Qabalistic Cross." It reaffirms the significance of Hermes and the Emerald Tablet as foundational to the Universal Tradition, explaining how the Three Supernals now directly influence Earth through Wisdom, Love, and Power. The chapter culminates with the symbol of "IU" representing the "One Thought of the Supreme and Concealed Father, as Manifested in the Ever-Coming Son," signifying the complete revelation and the ongoing presence of the divine.

key_concepts.definition: Frater Achad's re-arrangement of the Tarot Trumps on the Tree of Life, specifically reversing the traditional numbering of the Paths (11-32) from Malkuth upwards, rather than Kether downwards. This order is presented as restoring a "Primitive Universal Tradition" and revealing profound "Astrological Harmony," aligning the Qabalistic system with the "New Aeon."

A central archetypal figure representing the continuous manifestation of the divine, adapted across various mythological and astrological ages (e.g., Lion, Beetle, Twins, Calf, Lamb, Fish, and, in the New Aeon, Man in Aquarius). This concept underpins the "New Aeon" and the idea of God incarnating in every human heart as Ra-Hoor-Khuit.

The current spiritual epoch, inaugurated around 1904 with the reception of the Law of Thelema. It is characterized as a "purely Human Sign" where humanity has the unique opportunity to access "True Light of Wisdom and Understanding" and achieve Cosmic Consciousness, overcoming past limitations of Time and Space. It is associated with the Path of Aquarius as the only reciprocal and zodiacal path above the Abyss.

The process of restoring lost Equilibrium, canceling "Pairs of Opposites," and returning to the "Pure Conception of Unity." It involves uniting the Microcosm (Man) with the Macrocosm (Universe) by absorbing divine ideas, culminating in the self-realization of the Higher Self/Holy Guardian Angel and ultimately, identifying with the Divine Will.

Two historical streams of understanding the divine that Achad seeks to reconcile. The Sut-Typhonian (Dark) tradition emphasized the Mother and Child (Son preceding Father), a 365-day year, and a focus on Time/Matter. The Jupiter-Ammonian (Light) tradition emphasized solar Fatherhood and a 365.25-day year, but became limited. Achad's system demonstrates their reconciliation and transcendence in Tiphereth.

The central dictum, "Do what thou wilt shall be the whole of the Law," interpreted not as license but as the "strictest possible bond" and a "touchstone." It signifies aligning one's personal will with the Divine Will of Humanity as a Whole, fostering non-interference with others, and leading to conscious cooperation with Destiny, inner peace, and the manifestation of "Ever-Coming Sons of God."

The Infinitely Great (Continuous Matter, Mother of Stars) and the Infinitely Small (Inmost Essential Self, Flame in every heart/star) respectively. These two Infinites are united in the Crowned Child (Ra-Hoor-Khuit) and represent the ultimate reality of Existence, transcending the illusions of Time and Space. In Achad's reformulated system, Malkuth is Nuit, Kether is Hadit, and their union is Ra-Hoor-Khuit in Tiphereth.

Re-interpreted not as a diabolical figure but as MAN in his complete nature, embodying the harmonious synthesis of animal, human, spiritual, and divine qualities. Tiphereth is seen as the perfect image of The Beast, where all aspects of the Sun and the Son are harmonized, representing the highest evolutionary stage of humanity.

practical_system.description: The book presents a reformulated Qabalistic system centered on the "Reformed Astrological Order" of the Tree of Life. This system posits that by re-attributing the Tarot Trumps, planets, and zodiacal signs to the 22 Paths in a reversed, ascending order (starting Path 11 from Malkuth to Yesod), a "Primitive Universal Tradition" is recovered, aligning the system with the incoming "New Aeon" of Horus (Aquarius). The practical application involves meditating upon and internalizing these re-ordered correspondences to achieve a "world-view or vision" free from distortion, allowing the practitioner to consciously cooperate with the Divine Purpose and align their personal will with the True Will. It emphasizes that this integration leads to an expansion of consciousness, reconciling dualities (Light/Darkness, Personal/Divine Will) and culminating in the realization of the "Crowned Child" (Ra-Hoor-Khuit) within the heart. The "1923 Qabalistic Cross" is mentioned as a ritualistic tool for enlightening the subconscious and overcoming limitations.
tools: The Tree of Life diagram with the "Reformed Astrological Order" of the 22 Paths (as provided in the book).
The 22 Tarot Trumps, re-attributed according to the new order.
Knowledge of Hebrew letters and their Gematria (numerical values).
Astrological symbols (Planets, Zodiacal Signs) and their correspondences within the reformulated system.
The Book of the Law of Thelema (Liber CCXX) as a key text for understanding the "Word of Will."
rituals: Meditation and internalization of the re-ordered Tarot Trumps and Qabalistic correspondences for cosmic alignment.
Performance of the "1923 Qabalistic Cross" for enlightening the subconscious, overcoming the elemental forces of Water and Fire, and contacting the Holy Spirit.

relevant_quotes.text: The sin which is unpardonable is knowingly and willfully to reject truth, to fear knowledge lest that knowledge pander not to thy prejudices.
Do what thou wilt shall be the whole of the Law
That which is above is as that which is below, and that which is below is as that which is above, for the performing of the miracle of the One Thing
Kether is in Malkuth, and Malkuth is in Kether, but after another manner

I am that I am, the flame Hidden in the sacred ark. I am the unspoken name, I the unbegotten spark. I am He that ever goeth, Being in myself the Way; Known, that yet no mortal knoweth, Shown that yet no mortal showeth, I, the child of night and day. I am never-dying youth. I am Love, and I am Truth. I am the creating Word, I the author of the aeon; None but I have ever heard Echo in the empyrean Plectron of the primal paeon! I am the eternal one Winged and white, the flowering rod, I the fountain of the sun, Very God of Very God! I am he that lifteth up Life, and flingeth it afar; I have filled the crystal cup; I have sealed the silver star. I the wingless God that flieth Through my firmamental fame, I am he that daily dieth, And is daily born again.
I give unimaginable joys on earth, certainty, not faith, while in life upon death, peace unalterable, rest, ecstasy, nor do I demand aught in sacrifice.
First obtain the Knowledge and Conversation of the Holy Guardian Angel, the Higher Self, in Tiphereth the Kingdom of God in the Heart, and all things shall be added unto you.
I am a God of War and of Vengeance. I will deal hardly with them.

critical_analysis.relevance: Frater Achad's "The Egyptian Revival" is highly relevant within Western Esotericism, specifically Thelema and Qabalah, as it represents a foundational attempt to reformulate and re-contextualize the Tree of Life and Tarot system for the emerging "New Aeon." While his specific "Reformed Astrological Order" for the Paths of the Tree of Life (often called the "Achad Tree") was controversial and largely rejected by mainstream Thelemites (including Crowley himself, though Crowley initially encouraged Achad's work), it spurred significant re-evaluation of Qabalistic correspondences. The book demonstrates an early 20th-century occultist's earnest attempt to integrate newly rediscovered ancient Egyptian spiritual concepts with Hermetic Qabalah, astrological ages, and the philosophy of Thelema. It is a key historical document for understanding the development of Thelemic Qabalah and the intellectual milieu of early Thelema, influencing subsequent esoteric thought on the nature of cycles, divine manifestation, and the relationship between macrocosm and microcosm.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience for this book is advanced students and practitioners of Western Esotericism, particularly those steeped in Qabalah, Thelema, and Tarot. It assumes a pre-existing familiarity with the traditional Tree of Life, Hebrew alphabet, astrological symbols, and mythological archetypes. The dense, technical language and intricate web of correspondences make it unsuitable for beginners. It would also appeal to academic researchers in esotericism interested in the historical development of occult systems and the interpretations of seminal Thelemic figures beyond Aleister Crowley.
